screens.headline: Friday 4pm: Your broker just assigned you 100 shares
screens.text: You thought your option would just expire. Instead, you wake up Monday owning $25,000 of stock you didn't plan to buy. This happens to beginners who don't understand assignment. Let's make sure it never surprises you.

screens.headline: Exercise vs Assignment
screens.text: EXERCISE = YOU decide to use your option (buy or sell shares at strike). ASSIGNMENT = SOMEONE ELSE exercised and YOU'RE on the hook to deliver shares. Happens automatically if your option is ITM at expiration. Most traders SELL options before expiration to avoid this.

cards.definition: Using your option to buy/sell shares at strike price
cards.example: You own $100 call, stock at $120. Exercise = buy 100 shares at $100 (pay $10,000). Most traders SELL the option instead for cash.

cards.definition: Being forced to fulfill the obligation of an option you SOLD
cards.example: You sold a call. Someone exercised. You MUST deliver 100 shares at strike price. This is why beginners should only BUY options initially.

cards.definition: Broker auto-exercises ITM options at expiration
cards.example: Friday 4pm: You own $100 call, stock at $105. You forgot to sell it. Your broker exercises it automatically. Monday: you own 100 shares.

screens.headline: Early Assignment Risk - The Hidden Danger
screens.text: EARLY ASSIGNMENT = getting assigned BEFORE expiration. Can happen ANYTIME if your sold option is ITM. Most common triggers: dividends (call sellers), deep ITM options, day before expiration. Beginners think 'I'm safe until Friday' - WRONG. If you SOLD options, assignment can happen Monday, Wednesday, anytime. Stay alert!

cards.definition: Assignment CAN occur anytime your sold option is ITM
cards.example: Monday: Sold $45 put, stock at $44 (ITM). Someone COULD exercise early and assign you. Rare but possible. Be aware!

cards.definition: Assignment WILL occur at expiration if ITM by $0.01+
cards.example: Friday 4pm: Your sold put is ITM. 99% chance of assignment over weekend. Plan for it or close the position!

cards.definition: Call options often exercised early BEFORE ex-dividend date
cards.example: AAPL pays $0.25 dividend tomorrow. Your sold $180 call is ITM. Buyer exercises tonight to capture dividend. You lose stock + dividend!

cards.definition: Deep ITM options (>$10 ITM) have higher early assignment risk
cards.example: Stock at $60, you sold $45 put. It's $15 ITM. High chance someone exercises early. Close or roll the position!

screens.question: It's Thursday. Stock pays $2 dividend tomorrow (ex-div date). You sold ITM covered calls. What's the risk?
options: No risk - expiration is next Friday
HIGH RISK - you'll likely be assigned tonight to capture dividend
No risk - dividends don't affect options
screens.explanation_correct: CRITICAL awareness! Call buyers often exercise the night BEFORE ex-div date to capture the dividend. You wake up Friday: shares gone, you don't get the $2 dividend either. Solution: Close ITM calls BEFORE ex-div date or accept early assignment. This is the #1 early assignment trigger!
screens.explanation_wrong: This is the most common early assignment scenario! Buyer thinks: 'Exercise now, get $200 dividend tomorrow, vs wait for expiration and miss dividend.' They exercise. You lose shares AND dividend. ALWAYS close ITM calls before ex-dividend date!

screens.question: You sold a $45 cash-secured put. Stock drops to $42 on Wednesday (expiration is Friday). What's your early assignment risk?
options: LOW - possible but uncommon (stock would need to drop much more)
HIGH - you'll definitely be assigned early
screens.explanation_correct: Good assessment! Early assignment on puts is RARE (unlike calls with dividends). Most put holders wait until expiration to exercise. Exception: stock crashes hard (>20% ITM) or extreme market events. At $3 ITM, low early assignment risk. But be aware it CAN happen anytime you sold options!
screens.explanation_wrong: Low risk here. Early put assignment is uncommon unless stock crashes hard (>$10 ITM). Most put buyers wait until expiration. Your sold $45 put with stock at $42 = $3 ITM = probably safe until Friday. But monitor it - deep drops can trigger early assignment!

screens.headline: Early Assignment Risk Calculator
screens.description: Assess your early assignment risk level

outputs.label: Early Assignment Risk Level
outputs.calculation: (option_type == 'Covered Call' && dividend == 'Dividend tomorrow!' && itm > 0) ? '游댮 VERY HIGH - Likely tonight!' : (option_type == 'Covered Call' && dividend == 'Dividend in 3+ days' && itm > 5) ? '游리 MEDIUM - Watch closely' : (itm > 15) ? '游리 MEDIUM - Deep ITM' : (itm > 0 && dte < 2) ? '游리 MEDIUM - Near expiration' : '游릭 LOW - Monitor but OK'

outputs.label: What To Do
outputs.calculation: (option_type == 'Covered Call' && dividend == 'Dividend tomorrow!' && itm > 0) ? 'CLOSE TODAY or accept assignment!' : (itm > 15 || dte < 2) ? 'Consider closing or rolling position' : 'Monitor daily, be prepared for assignment'

outputs.label: Worst Case
outputs.calculation: option_type == 'Covered Call' ? 'Shares called away, lose stock + potential dividend' : 'Assigned shares at strike, now own stock (tie up capital)'

teaching_points: Try: Call, 7 DTE, $5 ITM, dividend tomorrow = HIGH RISK!
Try: Put, 14 DTE, $3 ITM, no dividend = LOW RISK
Try: Call, 1 DTE, $15 ITM = MEDIUM RISK (deep ITM)

screens.headline: Think of it like a concert ticket voucher
screens.text: You have a voucher for concert tickets at $50 each (your call option). The actual ticket price is now $200. You have three choices on the deadline day...

reveal_sections.label: SELL the voucher to someone else
reveal_sections.content: Your voucher is worth $150 ($200 - $50). Sell it for cash, never deal with actual tickets. This is what 95% of option traders do - SELL the option for profit.

reveal_sections.label: EXERCISE: Use voucher to buy tickets
reveal_sections.content: Pay $50, get tickets worth $200. Now you own tickets (must sell separately). Complicated. Only do this if you WANT to own the actual asset (shares).

reveal_sections.label: EXPIRE: Let voucher expire
reveal_sections.content: If tickets are $40 and your voucher is for $50, it's worthless. Let it expire. You lose the voucher cost, but you don't buy overpriced tickets.

reveal_sections.label: This is how options work
reveal_sections.content: SELL = get cash, easiest (most common). EXERCISE = get shares, complicated. EXPIRE = option worthless, lose premium.

screens.question: It's expiration Friday at 3:55pm. Your call is ITM by $10. What should you do?
options: Let it expire and collect profit automatically
SELL the option before 4pm to get cash
Do nothing - the broker handles it
screens.explanation_correct: Smart! Selling the option converts your profit to CASH instantly. No need to deal with shares, margin, or settlement. Exercise only if you WANT to own shares. 95% of option traders sell rather than exercise.
screens.explanation_wrong: If you do nothing, your broker will AUTO-EXERCISE at 4pm (if ITM). Monday morning, you'll own 100 shares = need $10,000+ in your account. Avoid this surprise! SELL the option for immediate cash profit before 4pm.

screens.question: You SOLD a covered call. Stock rocketed above your strike. What might happen?
options: You might get assigned - forced to sell shares at strike
You have to buy back the call
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! When you SELL options, you take on the OBLIGATION. If the buyer exercises, you're ASSIGNED. For covered calls, you must sell your 100 shares at the strike price. This is expected and OK - but beginners should understand this risk.
screens.explanation_wrong: When you SELL (not buy) options, you can be ASSIGNED. The buyer exercises their right, you fulfill the obligation. For covered calls, this means selling your shares at the strike. Often fine, but you need to understand it can happen anytime.

screens.question: Monday morning: Your account shows you own 100 shares of TSLA ($25,000 worth). You didn't buy them. What happened?
options: Your ITM call was auto-exercised over the weekend
screens.explanation_correct: Bingo! Friday 4pm: Your call was ITM. Your broker exercised it automatically. Saturday: Settlement processes. Monday: Shares appear in your account. If you don't have $25k cash, you're now on margin (borrowing). This is why you SELL before expiration!
screens.explanation_wrong: This is the 'surprise assignment' many beginners experience. Your ITM call was exercised automatically by your broker at expiration. Now you own shares. If you don't have the cash, you're on margin (borrowing) and paying interest. Avoid this: SELL the option before 4pm Friday!

screens.question: Your put is ITM by $5 at expiration. You don't own the underlying stock. What happens if you don't sell the put?
options: You're forced to SHORT 100 shares (advanced, risky)
screens.explanation_correct: Danger zone! Your put gives you the RIGHT to SELL shares at strike. But you don't own them. If exercised, you SHORT 100 shares = huge risk. Your broker may prevent this or force you to buy shares first. ALWAYS sell ITM puts before expiration if you don't own stock!
screens.explanation_wrong: ITM put at expiration without owning shares = your broker might: 1) Auto-exercise and SHORT shares (risky), 2) Sell the put automatically, or 3) Close your position. Every broker differs. Don't risk it - SELL the put before 4pm Friday for cash!

screens.question: Your call is OTM by $1 at 3:59pm on expiration Friday. What should you do?
options: Hold it - maybe it goes ITM in the last minute
Let it expire worthless - not worth the effort
screens.explanation_correct: Correct decision. OTM options are worthless. Selling it might get you $1-5, but after commissions, it's not worth it. Let it expire. Accept the loss. Move on to the next trade. This is part of options trading.
screens.explanation_wrong: With 1 minute left and OTM, your option is basically worthless. Yes, you could sell for $1-2, but after commissions you might net zero. Professional traders let these expire and focus on their next opportunity. Don't waste energy on pennies.

cards.front: What do 95% of option traders do?
cards.back: SELL the option before expiration for cash. Never exercise, never get assigned. Treat options like trading cards - buy low, sell high, collect cash. Avoid the complexity of shares.
If your option is ITM by $0.01+ at 4pm Friday, most brokers auto-exercise. Monday: you own shares (calls) or are short shares (puts). Avoid surprise: sell before 4pm or have cash ready.

cards.front: Early assignment - when does it happen?
cards.back: ANYTIME if you SOLD an ITM option. Most common: day before ex-dividend date (calls), deep ITM (>$10), day before expiration. Close ITM options before ex-div dates! Monitor daily if deep ITM.
Only option SELLERS have assignment risk. If you only BUY options, you control when/if to exercise. You can't be assigned. This is why beginners should stick to buying initially.

screens.badge_description: You understand assignment AND early assignment risk!
screens.celebration_message: Critical knowledge! You now know when assignment happens (expiration) AND when early assignment can surprise you (dividends!). Stay alert! 游닓
